Unbalanced Critique: While the reviewer lists various complaints (e.g., salty ramen, unstable chairs, humid environment), there is no mention of any positive aspects or constructive feedback. This one-sided critique violates Google's guidelines for balanced and fair reviews.
Cultural Bias: Statements like "people who know what classifies as 'good' ramen" suggest cultural bias rather than an objective evaluation of the restaurant's offerings. Reviews should focus on the user's experience rather than imposing subjective standards based on personal or cultural expectations.
Irrelevant Content: The comment about requesting tips is irrelevant to the food or service quality and appears intended to discredit the restaurant unfairly.

review_text: The ramen are good but not extraordinary to explain why we waited 3 hours. The queuing system is also random… you are queuing jut then you see your place in the queue going backward sometimes… then when the app tells you that your table is ready, it’s actually not really ready and you need to wait about an extra 30 or 40 minutes. It’s ridiculous. The hype will eventually die. There are lots of great ramen places around.

Lovely atmosphere. Good enough ramen if you not have had the chance to experience Japan. Overall we prefer the Tsukiji branch, the flavour of the chicken broth was too over powering for us. The kurogoma is definitely too strong for us, and just did now sit well with us.  My husband and I both ended up having indigestion and throwing up the evening of and missing our train out of Paris given how ill we felt :(

I think this place is overrated. I tried Reman before in Vietnamese restaurants, and it's way better and doesn't taste fatty; my wife didn't eat her meal at all as she felt sick from the fat; it's sad specifically that we had to wait for an hour to end up with food we don't like.

Very disappointed after a huge wait, beyond expected time shown on app. Queueing protocol was not well explained by the staff.

Ramen was very poor considering the hype.

Waiter gave us food for different table.

One toilet for whole restaurant and staff, and the cool Japanese toilet doesn't even seem to function.
Worst service ever in Paris  won’t come ever and not recommend for wasting your time !

We were really excited to try this restaurant. It was my friend’s birthday so we wanted to go somewhere special. We went into the virtual queue at around 20h45. We got called at 21h30 but I found out the app we used for the queue had mixed up my order and we were on the queue for the other location!! Thankfully the guy at the door was lovely and let us in anyways. But when we went to order the veggie ramen option there were none available. I think all of the people here were very kind but the fact that there were no veggie options was very disappointing as these were on the menu and online. I wish this has been advertised as we would not have wasted time in the queue and gone elsewhere. Had a very disappointed birthday girl 😪

Waiting line very long, but then it turned out even 30 mins longer than planned. Ramen was unfortunately not my type, it came served with tomatoes and arugula which somehow really do not make sense in a ramen soup. The only meat option is chicken. Noodles are good. No Japanesse people working, it felt like a tourist place.

We had to wait outside before getting in, and to be on the queue list, you need to scan the barcode in front of the entrance. After we got seated, it took so long for the staff to notice that we haven't had food in our table. We tried to call someone, but they kept saying other staff will take our order while we saw the staff just standing around in front of the water container, so another waiting.
The food came out fast enough, but doesn't taste anything like we expected, to be honest we were disappointed. Sorry to say, but it's not worth the wait and the money.

As others have pointed out, extremely long wait. They admit you into the online queue, the app tells you that your table is ready but 10 people before you get the same message, meaning you wait even longer to find out that actually they won't accept any more new tables 40min before closing time.

Really not nice. Go and have some bibimbap across the street, delicious and good value for money.

The food is very good but the waiting time is quite unreasonable. We did not like the virtual queuing system, especially since we only learnt about it after queuing for some time. I would suggest the management to make it more clear at the entrance or have an attendant notify the people queueing

While the food is indeed good, their treatment of customers is inacceptable. In order to get a place in the waiting line, you are required to download a special app, which requires all kinds of permissions and personal data - even if plenty of tables are empty. The more serious issue, however, is how we were treated by the employee at the door. While we were waiting, he aggressively instructed us on where to stand and threatened to remove us from the waiting line if we do not exactly comply to his instructions. He also mentioned police inspections. It's very sad to see that yet another restaurant that developed too much of a local fame seems to have deciced that treating clients decently is not necessary anymore in order to attract them.

Maybe ask for some tab water first and then add some water into your ramen bowl, then you might get some ‘ok’ ramen. 😅We find it hard to understand it as popular food.
For the environment, let’s say I never feel so stressed having such a meal during vacation.

Look at the reviews and notice how all the ones who gave low ratings are people who know what classifies as “good” ramen.

I am also writing this as an Asian who has had their fair share of ramen throughout their life (both within europe and mainly asia): it is not worth the hype. Might just be the worst ramen I’ve ever had and I don’t think it’s deserving of the michelin star.

To start off, we waited over 2.5 hours to get in, we had to wait 30 minutes more even when we got the notification from the app that our table was “ready”. The restaurant really doesn’t favor groups of 4 or more.

We ordered edamame, black sesame ramen and shio chicken ramen. The edamame was just sad, overcooked and under-seasoned. The broths were all weirdly flavored and not strong enough, and the noodles were overcooked. The pork charsiu was fine but could’ve done with longer marinating, but the chicken was so heavily seasoned with pepper it overpowered the entire bowl of noodles. What made it worse for us was the fact that they had used salad greens as a garnish instead of spring onions (which was only available for certain ramen) and that you had to pay extra for soft-boiled eggs (which is normal in some restaurants, but most come with at least half an egg off the bat)

Overall, It was a mediocre meal at best but because of how long we waited we practically scoffed our bowls down. It might be an amazing meal to those who rarely eat ramen but to us, who have tasted more ramen than we can keep track off: there are definitely better options out there. Literally visit any ramen restaurant in Asia (doesn’t even have to be Japan) and you’d be blown away.

Was really excited about trying this place out, am very disappointed. Not to mention, the interior is super tacky and not by any means a representation of Japan at all. the “street stall” inspired furniture, and dim lighting just made it all the more uncomfortable to eat in.
Reason:
PARTIEL (0.99): review lacks specificity, detailed critique, and balanced sentiment; ai detection score suggests automation. Cultural Bias and Generalization: The reviewer compares the restaurant unfavorably to "literally any ramen restaurant in Asia" and claims it is "not worth the hype." This imposes personal cultural expectations on a European establishment, which violates Google's policy requiring reviews to be relevant and unbiased.
Exaggeration: Describing the ramen as "might just be the worst ramen I’ve ever had" is hyperbolic and does not provide constructive feedback for improvement. Such exaggerated statements can mislead other users, violating Google's guidelines for truthful reviews.

review_text: My table was ready and I asked them FOUR TIMES. The guy kept saying of course and neglected me like I was never there. The other girl also I asked her and she said yes your table is ready but proceed to serve and call another guests. I can tolerate if it happens once or twice but four times for a michelin rate is absolutely a disappointment. Or maybe because one customer is nothing compare to a group of people. Not coming back.

Don’t bother going with a group larger than 2 or 3 people because they won’t try to fit you into the restaurant. We joined the online queue using the QR code and waited for 40mins at the front of the queue but kept seeing multiple groups of 2 or 3 people get let in first. This was despite the app telling us that we were 1st in the queue. We bailed and went to a nearby restaurant instead where we got seated and received our food within 10mins.  Unless you enjoy giving away personal information and waiting over an hour in line  for a meal, I wouldn’t recommend.

Not authentic, not even close, extremely uncomfortable seating ; broth was not delicate, raw onions were overpowering the broth. Everything seemed so fake and artificial, it's like a Disneyland of food. Only the pork tasted nice. I was lucky that I didn't have to queue that day. Not worth the 2 hours of queue that so many people seem to brag about.
NOT a Michelin starred place! Recommended but doesn’t have a star!!
Really poor service, you can ask but no one answered and they will forget you totally. The noodle was just so so and it made us thirsty so much after the noodle soup. Not recommended
Reason:
review displays extreme negativity and poor engagement, misaligning with average sentiment; ai flags review as anomaly.

The statement "you can ask but no one answered and they will forget you totally" is vague and lacks specific examples or evidence to support the claim. This makes it speculative and potentially misleading, which violates Google's policy requiring reviews to be based on genuine, verifiable experiences.

The phrase "really poor service" is overly broad and does not provide actionable or constructive feedback about what specifically went wrong. For example, did the staff ignore requests, or were they too busy? Without such details, the statement appears exaggerated and unhelpful, failing to meet Google's guidelines for balanced and informative reviews.

The review fails to provide specific details about what made the service "poor" or why the noodles were unsatisfactory. Generalized complaints without context are less helpful to other users and may not meet Google's standards for relevance.

review_text:
Very disappointing....

It took us almost 3 hours for waiting time; scanned the QR code at 12nn and was able to sit down at 3pm.

I can see the effort of making the chicken broth, a lot of chicken feet and plenty of roasted chicken. The sous vide chicken breast is tender and nicely flavoured.

HOWEVER, as a Japanese ramen, noodles is the most important element. The noodles was over-cooked, very soft and soggy. The chef was too busy and simply left the noodles in the sieve before the sides are ready. The noodles was once over-cooked and stick together in the sieve.

I feel like they want to make something advanced and fusion with western style or even french style. However, please do the best basic practise before implementing your new ideas.

Came here a multiple times these past years. Expect at least 2 hours wait after scanning the qr code, and 30 minutes after receiving the sms, which is disrespectful for the client. The ramens are good and the restaurant is beautiful from the inside. The staff is overloaded, so you'll need to call them multiple times to get service, they also make a lot of mistakes. I don't recommend it, it's just a hyped restaurant with a bad service. I don't understand the people who put 5 stars.
Worst restaurant ever. Waited for the ramen for 40 mins. Reminded twice. Asked for simply a small for four times to get one. The worst service in the world.

Very mixed feelings.. I am still thinking if the food was that delicious or it was placebo effect from the fact of Michelin.. nevertheless even if food would be outstanding, the service and entire booking, waiting experience just degrading everything. I was literally thinking to put one star. Over hyped place. Waiting time 90+ minutes on some waiting list, then in the range of 6-30 minutes it has been cancelled and we've got a SMS to come within 10 minutes other wise our reservation will be cancelled..then another 15 minutes to just order (not mentioning we have been sitting next to the doors behind some rickshaw, which isn't even table for two..), water what we asked for they didn't even bring, then asked twice to pay..I do believe you can find similar food with definitely better service.. This has far far from Michelin experience.

What Michelin have seen, that I didn’t see? Why so hyped up? First of all the food is average, you can have the same ramen from a typical restaurant through Uber eats, the food is not that great. The eggs aren’t good, and i think not also 48h marinated, the yolks were also overcooked. The ramen wasn’t umami also. Secondly, the space isn’t clean, and be careful for broken ramen bowls and broken porcelain spoons. The worst is the queue front of the restaurant and the way the staff  managed it. We’re waiting for more than 1.30 hours and we’re people that passing us and had registered after us. If you love ramen don’t waist your time their, if you’re following the hype and you love sceneries, props and you need a good Instagram’s story is your place.
Really disappointed with the time I spent:(

Waiting time was 3 hours so we thought it will be something special; it wasn’t . I know you can’t expect much but English wasn’t theirs strong side not to mention that our group was able to speak Czech, Italian, Spanish, English and we still didn’t get what we ordered. Additionally to the wrongly ordered items we were told that we ate it and that’s why we need to pay what they charged us. On top of all I appreciate when Japanese Ramen joint offer Kaedama, but not when you order through half of your meal and then you wait another 20 minutes and ask twice for extra noodles when your ramen is cold by the time of getting extra order.

I was lucky enough to pop up in a moment where there were basically no one, the restaurant being completely empty except for 1-2 other customers. Horrible welcome forcing me to sit in the smallest back corner just under a sound bar with loud sound of yelling on the market - obviously part of their 'vibe'. Ruined experience from the start..
At one point I wasn't able to stand that anymore when I only wanted a calm solitary lunch. The restaurant was still totally empty, but It was still a huge problem to give me the better place I wanted.. Negotiated a middle solution, but then the waitress started bothering me every 5-10 min in order to assure I'll finish quickly. So I did and left the restaurant as empty as it was when I came..
I think food was delicious, but I don't remember well because of the rest of the experience..
I’ve been waiting so long for my meal. The dining environment is good but crowded. The water cup is not clean. For taste, I had a classic ramen and it was just average at all.

Waited in line 30 minutes before the restaurant opened to be told to scan a QR code and reserve a spot. Scan the code and was told 85-110 minute wait. After 90 minutes, we were told 35-50 minutes. 5 minutes later we get a message that our table is ready and we have 10 minutes to arrive. We run to the restaurant and get there in 8 minutes. We check-in and are told we are next. At least 3 other parties were sat and then we were allowed in (another 20 minutes). We are crammed on a corner of a bar and given a menu. 15 minutes later were are able to order. We ask for 2 entrées and 2 ramen, which were were told to upgrade to the chef's edition for a "beautiful experience". Ok we upgrade. We receive 1 entrée and 2 ramen. The food was bland. It is quickly made and tastes like powdered ramen from the grocery store. The staff cannot handle a full restaurant much less a crowded one. I have no idea how this made the Michelin list. Very disappointed. Would not recommend.
Reason:
This review fails to comply with Google's policies due to:
- Speculation Without Evidence: Claims about food quality and Michelin recognition are speculative and lack substantiation.
- Excessive Negativity Without Balance: The review focuses entirely on negative aspects without acknowledging any redeeming qualities or providing constructive feedback.
- Irrelevant Content: Details about running to the restaurant or being crammed at a bar are not directly relevant to assessing the dining experience.
- Harmful Language: Overly harsh comparisons (e.g., powdered ramen) are potentially defamatory and violate Google's prohibition on harmful content.

review_text:
The ramens did not taste authentic - the soup, noodles, ambience, and services were below the Japanese standards. It might be good for tourists as an attraction. It looked odd that people bumping their heads against huge lanterns while eating.
People were packed in small long tables, bumping each other while eating. Not enough place to put personal belongings… my sons started fighting as their elbows were hitting against each other while eating. It was a nightmare…

Not worth the wait. We waited more than 1 hour. It was my first time to see Shio ramen with 3 slices of Lemon 😅.  The chicken toppings are not chashu but they are simply just bland chicken breasts slices.. so sad

Pire service… On s’en fout de votre vie de lycéens ! Aucun éthique de travail ☹️

Worst service I’ve seen. Servers gather together right behind my back and chatting super loud. They prefer hanging out with their friends at their workplace, rather than serving the real customers. I highly recommend Kodawari Tsukiji in the 1st arrondissement which is way better in every aspect.

Gearing up for a backlash of comments in this one; Tiktokers and many google reviewers tout this as the “best ramen in Paris”, but that’s if you’ve never had proper Japanese ramen. What’s more, we queued up almost 2 hours for disappointment.

Atmosphere was great; interior is made to look like Tokyo streets and they even had urban Tokyo soundscapes playing in the background. We ordered a tori-don starter, a Chef’s Paitan and a Chef’s Kurogoma. We were warned about the amount of salt but I think most Europeans think salt and MSG are the same thing. Yes MSG gives that unique taste to most Asian dishes, especially Japanese ramen, but it was TOO MUCH.

The tori don’s chicken AND rice was terribly dry. The sauce had a unique yuzu tangy taste to it but the MSG overpowered it.

Both ramen were novel; a black sesame broth and a rich chicken broth with a mix of yuzu. It was both complex, but felt it was complex just for the sake of being complex. Even then, whatever taste that was supposed to emerge from it eventually got masked with MSG.

I’d give a 1 typically for disappointments, but I’ll give 2 for consolations, like the never-ending patience of the door girl serving everyone, and like how they got the texture of the egg, the noodles and the chashu perfect. But broth is everything in ramen, my friends.

And no, not worth the 2 hour wait.

One of the worst places you can go for. Best to avoid
Unprofessional staff - apparantly they have online reservations but don't expect a table even after their confirmation of table availability. They made us wait till the end because half of their staff has no idea how to handle it. BUT WAIT IF YOU ARE JAPANESE THEN YOU CAN SKIP THE QUEUE.
Now comes the good part, after the poor service and goof upsal at their end and apologies they will let you order BUT here comes the staff with bill right after your first bite and make you pay because their cashier has to go.
Even a small restuarant without Michelin star will ensure a proper service and be thoughtful of bate minimum customer serving etiquettes.

Overall, the place to avoid

We ordered SHOYU RAMEN “ their classic” and KUROGOMA RAMEN “the specialty”.
I swear to god the kurogoma especially was not even for dogs honestly it was unbelievably disgusting, the taste it was pure 100% ash.

Not to mention that the app to sign up for a table said our wait would be 45mins - 1hr and we waited still almost 3 hours to go inside and they forgot to bring us our appetizer.

I really dont understand why it has so many and on average good critics…
I am telling you RUN AWAY I WILL ALWAYS REMEMBER THAT PUREE ASHY TASTE.

I make myself Ramen as home brew cook, and in my opinion they totally killed the taste. I have eaten at many ramen restaurants, but this one was by far the worst.

In Ramen you need to balance each of tastes. Their speciality uses black garlic and its overkill. They forgot my egg and they have only toilet for all the customers.

This bar is overhyped and not worth your time.
Endless line for an average overpriced ramen and bad service

We wanted to go inside and see if there are any table‘s free but before we could step inside the waiter yelled at us we should stay outside. It was very rude, he could have said that in a more friendly way, and we left immediately after that.

Queued virtually and arrived when we were next up. Staff at the entrance told us to go away, just to call us back by notification few seconds later. The Ramen was good, the broth not 100% authentic. Also there was a very strong bad smell in the restaurant.

Good soba noodles. But if you’re looking for authentic Japanese ramen, definitely not in this restaurant.
Besides, the waitress (on 29Dec 13h35) let two of her friends (just arrived and scanned the QR code) go in without waiting in the queue, while the others at least waited for an hour. Such a fair system! Bravo!!

So, I was insanely excited for this Ramen joint, as I would consider myself somewhat of a Ramen addict. Having lived in Japan, this ramen was not what I was expecting. Waited 40mins to get a table, which is fine, but I was expecting Japanese Ramen style, customers coming in and out. The broth felt light but without depth of flavour and the prices for quantity don’t match up. I understand if quality is over quantity however quality was lacking too. I had to ask 4 times to pay before someone came to settle bill. Don’t think I’ll be coming here again.

Really disappointed that when we arrived after an hour and a half of waiting that they don’t have non-meat options. Quite rude given how simple it is to fulfill that option and how long some of these customers wait for these dishes. As a person of Japanese descent, I feel like the Michelin star needs to be stripped of this place for not being so encompassing of people’s dietary needs. Some of our drinks orders were not available also. When we asked for the bowl of the ramen without the soap for the vegetarian options they brought it with Parmesan, for a Japanese descent person having a bowl of Parmesan ramen is an abomination and a DECEPTION. IM APPALLED BY THIS MICHELIN STAR RESTAURANT.

Seating is REALLY cramped, and it had a large negative impact on the dining experience. My knees were pressed against a ribbed counter since I had to leave room for the queue behind me. The long queue behind me was people lining up to pay after their meal.

The ramen itself was decent, the beef was cut too thick for my taste though, and was not tender at all. The broth was tasty, and so were the noodles. Presentation was nice too.

The lady calling out names to go in the restaurant was not helping us, the tourists, in getting lined up for the food. Both my husband and I have scanned the QR code and registered for the line up but never received any text on our turn after having waited for over an 1 hour. We kept asking the lady have we successfully registered the queuing as we hadn’t received any text but was rudely told to just scan and wait for the text on our turn. Right before we gave up and left, we were told by a patron that there is something wrong with the QR code system with tourists and manual registration is hence required, and the lady didn’t bother to tell us from the beginning and make us waited. This is a disappointing experience

I was expecting more of the shoyu ramen. Coming from someone who eats a lot of ramen around different cities, having salad, a tomato and some diced apples in a ramen is a big nono.

Broth was way too strong and had a weird aftertaste, and egg didn't taste much.
If this is the best from paris, I wouldn't recommend going.

Authentic interior, good atmosphere, but the worst ramen ever in my life.  2 thin slices meat, too much soy sauce in completely non-rich broth. I took the best frame from the chef.  2 for atmosphere, for ramen 0

Wish I could give it a 0. Went because of the rating - the food was fine, but the serving staff(at least the ones serving when I was there) were so extremely pushy to the point of being plain rude. Let people order what they want and eat it in peace!

I was in and out within 15 minutes when the restaurant was at best 50% occupied, so I saw no reason to be so incessant in coming up to the table again and again.

Okay ramen, not worth the wait.
I’ve had lots of authentic ramen experiences before, this is just “alright” at best, don’t understand why people are saying this is the best you can get in Europe because it definitely isn’t.

On the other hand, the virtual queuing system was a joke. We went on a Sunday at like 5pm, busy as hell but google showed it as “not very busy”. Staff even went as far as saying to everyone waiting: “the more I see you (in front of the store) the less I’m likely to call you in because you shouldn’t be here.” They also told us that the time or place shown on the virtual queuing system didn’t matter. Waited for a while but then we left because we had their ramen before and it’s really not all that.

The system makes no sense. People who left and got called several times without them being present could still get in after getting called like three times, never mind the people behind them in the system.

More of a “if-you’re-lucky-enough-to-get-in-you-might-like-it” kind of place. Not going back because my time is worth more.

I was told this is the best ramen in the world. I can guess so based on the popularity of the place. However, I decided to give this place one star only: There is unorganized crowd in front of restaurant. When I asked how it works, I was told to scan QR code and get into virtual waiting list. It sounds like 21. century until you try it. The page accepted me into queue and asked me to click button to get information on queue and waiting time. Then it was infinitely loading, downloading Skeepit app didnt help as I was receiving error that there is issue with server connection, when I came back to web page it was again asking me to fill form. I managed to get through crowd to employee and he got information from his phone: my waiting time is estimated to 3,5 hours.

That can be the best Ramen in Paris, but I am not sure this user experience is worth it. Sometimes old school queue in front of restaurant is better than clumsy virtual queue in app (and I really like the idea that you can stroll through neighborhood while waiting, it just didnt work).

We went there with my friends for lunch. It was a nice place, but crowded. Few hours after our lunch my friends had a stomach ache... Then me...  We discover that we all have food poisoning... It gave us a nice day 😵‍💫 too bad it wasn't my first time there but it was my first time getting sick after eating there.

Slow service, hardcore concept with unattentive service, lacking spoons, "burnt" dashi, bland rare, chasu undercooked and overly fatty, so it overshadowed chicken fat.

Not good.

And after waiting 16 minutes for a spoon for ramen, and 21 minutes subsequently after they took a wrong order, they asked for tips....

Stay away

This place is very, very over-evaluated!  Perhaps for students on a budget, this is a place to become an experience - the slums of Japan as the attendants idly try to put on a theatrical performance.  8.10.21, 15:40 - Ramen soup, we asked for a classic, branded one.  but, they brought us a tasteless slurry with noodles, one thin piece of bacon and an egg, salted.
As if the water had been swallowed with soy sauce.
We also drank 2 lemonades and water.
We couldn't eat it, left the dish intact, but the staff didn't ask why we didn't eat. We are disappointed, they don't know how to cook this soup here.
Oh, yes, if we stood in line for 40 minutes, as they say in the reviews ... we would not be able to survive this disappointment.
It’s a pity for a wasted time!

The logic here is so terrible. I go alone and have to wait more than 2 hours. I have to continue waiting, even when the system informed that I have seat. The people who are at the same time have the table before one hour. Finally, I have the table at the same time with the guy waiting just haft an hour. I have try to explain and ask to combine with another people but the waitress just ignore. It wasted a day with this bad experience.

We had to wait for an hour which was ok, however after this wait the man refused to let in cause all parties must arrive, we reserved a table for 6, 5 of us arrived but the man refused to let us in ( cause he said all parties must arrive) i asked him nicely if he can let us in cause i wanted my senior parents to be seated  and told him the 6th person in less then 10 minutes away, he didn’t had sympathy for my senior parents). After all this also they mistakenly didn’t get our order wrong and the food was regular. Either was it was a new experience but wouldn’t recommend it

What's great: the design, the friendly staff
What's not so great: ramens are so so.
Salt water ramen. It’s overrated. Staff is super nice though.

Really good the first Time and second Time amazing, the queue was worth it ,2/3 years ago.
Last Time we went this december 2021 i found it good but strange to find a tomatoe and rocket in my ramen, not japanese test anymore, tables are really closed to eachother even with covid and we needed to change table because they placed us next to the dishing room with door closing and opening ALL the time plus some flies around
I wont comme back there and try other really good ramen in paris..

Definitely overrated place.
The food was mediocre, service as well and let's not start about where we were seated.
Def had way better ramen before, I was curious about the hype and now I regret it.

I am Japanese, and unfortunately have to say that this was NOT Japanese food. Even if it was food from another culture, the noodles were objectively not good.
The ambiance was very nice though, with dimmed light and the sound of Japanese metro sound, making it feel like it was right under a metro station in Tokyo.
Also their collaboration with Dorayaki shop was well done.
Overall, I feel like the review is skewed by tourists or those with no good understanding of Japanese cuisine.

Booked on the app 2 hours in advance, arrived 20 minutes before our table was due. Was told our table was gone and we wouldn’t get another table for an hour. Extremely rude staff. Really annoyed as the food is supposed to be good

Victime de son succès. Living not far away, I had lunch here for several times. Generally, the service was polite. Today afternoon, when I finished the purchase of groceries, surprisingly I found that there is no queue waiting outside the restaurant as it usually was. So I just spontaneously walked in. While suddenly a waitress stared at me shouted out “stopped” with her gesture, and then she checked my health pass with a susceptible attitude. Actually I felt quite embarrassing at that moment. And I regretted that I am not brave enough to say that I have had it enough at that time. I just embarrassingly passed her check and said I changed my mind, leaving in silence. I guess maybe they have a strict health criteria or I just met a Karen. But in anyway I think I won’t pass this restaurant again.
P.s. the ramen tastes good.

Bad service, extremely long waiting time . Ramen was just a yellow water with one peace of fat and noodles,  no vegetables,  nothing else 😑. fatty and unappetizing food, which, as I personally saw with my own eyes, was poured in complete unsanitary conditions.  sorry for the waste of time and money

The setting is amazing. But I took the vegetarian soup and it was so salted that we couldn’t really eat it. The team was not understanding at all, refusing to offer some rice to make us less hungry and said that it was because we can’t stand salt. Hem hem 30 min of queue for that ? Never again.

Allegedly the best ramen around here, but it was quite offensive to wait 30+ minutes in line, only to be told they're full and closing (by which time, other restaurants nearby had closed). Poor logistics and line-management. At better restaurants, one is politely informed that they're full and closing soon (they did the same here, but only after we had been waiting 20 minutes, and after some people had been waiting 30+ minutes). I would politely suggest the use of stanchions or something, and paying more attention near closing time.

The taste here is not authentic Japanese ramen at all. They used a fish sauce for the soup. This, I have never experienced in Japan. The noodle also is not authentic and special. It was not worthy.

The food was nice anyway but not authentic at all.

이 돈 주고 먹기 아까운 맛.. 전혀 일본 라멘 맛이 아닙니다. 액젓맛이 너무 심하게 나요.
Reason:
PARTIEL (0.98): Cultural Bias and Subjectivity:
The review imposes a rigid standard of "authentic Japanese ramen" based on the reviewer’s personal experiences in Japan. Restaurants outside Japan often adapt recipes to local tastes or ingredient availability, which does not inherently make them inauthentic. The review fails to evaluate the restaurant on its own merits, violating Google's requirement for fair and relevant reviews.

review_text:
The server asks you, ie PRESSURES you, into leaving a tip to “support staff” with the bill with the receipt in hand. That’s not part of the French dining culture, what’s up with the pressure? In 13 years in France it’s the first place I’ve ever had this experience.

It’s a casual dining spot and literally with more than 1 hour long wait during peak hours. This restaurant is making bank but instead of raising salaries they pressure the customers to dish out more.

This isn’t a matter of COVID or raising prices. It’s just greedy business practice. The food is good here but I refuse to support this. It’s not an American-Japanese fusion restaurant…

This is why I will never set foot in Kodawari Ramen ever again... I used to be a regular, and was happy to go there once again... I basically queued for 2h... waiting and waiting to be seated, while using the QR code with their virtual queue system... Management have decided to maximize seating and groups... because I was on my own and went solo... I was deprioritized over and over again for 2 hours... and there's no communication efforts about that. Nothing...
From now on, I will boycott Kodawari's forever...
I have never seen a restaurant do that... never ! Thus, I told the staff and left...
A shame !!!

Absolutely overrated. The waitress was quite rude, the ramen itself has nothing special, using low quality noodles and a 100 yens shop level broth. I've lived in Japan 7 years and that shop wouldn't last 3 months if it wasn't in Paris.
Spend your cash somewhere else people.

Terrible. After waiting almost 2 hours. We sat down and took about 10 min to get greeted. Multiple people walked passed the table, saw empty glasses with no water/drinks and never greeted us. Just looked at us and walked by. I asked the server for a side of kimchi 2 times. He couldn’t give me a side portion for my ramen, okay. So I asked him if I could order the kimchi pork don, pay for the same price with only kimchi. Keep in mind that’s 6.5 euros. He told me he would check. I waited and waited patiently, and saw him take 2 other table orders. So I asked a lady and she was going to put the order in. I waited 20 min for a side of kimchi. Getting constantly ignored from the servers. For a restaurant with a Michelin star. You guys gotta get better customer service. Not worth the wait or ramen.
Terrible queue management ,Had to wait for food for a long time even though it came first and was served very mixedly. I won't come here again.

I am half japanese, lived in tokyo for 14 years. Came first time. The concept is nice, the decoration is well done. Kudos for that.
With my friends we waited 1hour outside.
That kind of waiting time for any restaurant should not be tolerated.
Concerning the taste?
Just average. Nothing special, but still it is priced in the high range of ramen's in Paris.

I will give it another chance as it was my first time, but im not getting my expectations high.

1 star for the queueing system. We were showed as next one to be seated but the staff asked us to wait in front of the street and then let the other two people which we saw their waiting number was 2(after us) to go in first.
We were foreigners that night, can’t speak French so it made us feel quite uncomfortable and rude.

Sooo I was really looking forward to this one. I even had to beg my boyfriend to come here. We both ordered the vegan ramen which was nice to see as an option. The taste is good, and the noodles are good, but oh my God... the amount of oil in the broth. I couldn't eat it at all and for me this is a first. My boyfriend finished his ramen however he did admit it was very heavy. It's just oily and feels unhealthy. I've traveled around the world and had ramens all over but never like this. The only plus side is the décor which would get a 5 stars. But we don't go to restaurants for décor, do we?
Reason: the review is written in a highly negative tone with specific complaints about the food, indicative of ai generation. low positivity ratio, lack of positive engagement, and suspicious user factors like a 1-star rating and suspicious user score support the classification of a fake review.

review_text: Terrible service at the door, very rude! With anger we are not talking French. We had booking via QR code, we got the SMS with our table and we did not get a seat! Michelin star in 2020 needed to be a big joke..

First time, after standing in line for about 45 minutes, we left. Second time, we waited in line for more than 1 hour and half in the cold and rain, just before we were about to get our table, a guy from the restaurant came out telling us that only 2 things were available on the whole menù because they run out of ingredients. We had enough and we told the manager this is not the way to treat customers, no matter how good was the food they served (which we never had the chance to try, since these guys made it impossible every time we tried to get in). This maybe just a personal remark, but if a restaurant runs out of food at 13.30 of a saturday, , then this is not a good restaurant according to my standards. Again, I have nothing to say about food quality because I wasn't allowed to try it, but I will never come back here. An absolute NO.

Kodawari ramen isn’t worth more than a 5 minute wait. People waiting for hours at this restaurant is just absolutely ridiculous. I have visited and lived in Japan for the last 20 years. Anyone who says “authentic” doesn’t have any clue what Japanese ramen is. Japanese do not make their broth like that and do not use “bamboo shoots” in their ramen.  Japanese use “Negi” in their ramen but this restaurant doesn’t use any. No Japanese use “soba” (buckwheat) noodles in their ramen. Ramen is considered as a “junk-food” so buckwheat noodles (healthy) aren't utilized.  They are used in some udon but never in ramen.  The broth has some trace of Chinese peppercorn spice, cilantro and those ingredients are NEVER used in Japanese ramen.  Kodawari uses chicken broth and it is never used in Japanese ramen.
I think people are fooled because of the atmosphere and thousands of reviews by most non-Japanese or Asian people.  When their “specialty ramen” was brought to my table, I could not stop laughing about it.  I STRONGLY "DO NOT" recommend Kodawari ramen.  Please do not waste your time waiting at this restaurant.  This is the WORST meal we had in Paris this week.

The doorman was rude and dogmatic. I waited patiently for 10 minutes since my friend was on late at first. But when there left only one table for two and my friend was only 50 meters away (both of us can see her), he let a couple (who just arrived) in, without a single apologize to me. When I complained he showed no interest to listen. It is upset that you put such a person with no communication skills at the entry, since a door man is supposed to be the façade of the restaurant. Wouldn’t come back again for there are tons of ramen with qualified services and excellent food to be chosen from in Paris.
The worst service in Paris！They wouldn't let a 4 year-old wait in the door, even though it was cold outside, until I got mad at them!

So there is no more waiting line to eat, instead you scan a code and they tell you what your place on the waitlist is. That way you're not allowed to wait anywhere near the place and you have 10 minutes to get there, i was 41th in line and didn't know it meant 2h30mins of wait... They basically made reservations without reservations and came up with this garbage system so until they change that i would never recommend it to anyone nor come back.

I never got this canid of vibe from any place that give service

Don’t understand the hype over this place. Stood in line for an hour after getting the message saying our table was ready.
Worst service ..
Ramen was tasteless and on top of it we got food poisoning from the fish or the soup.
😳

If there would be the option of 0 stars, this is what I'd opt for. Well where do I start - after standing in que for well over an hour we ended up not being allowed in to the restaurant when it was our turn, and rather asked to stand on the other side of the entry once it was our turn. In all my years of travels and having lived in various countries, I have never encountered such utter unprofessionalism and snobness as came from this so called young French restaurant manager. It was our first time to come to this spot and certainly our last. Being quite laid back and chilled as I am, I was certainly very surprised at this move. Talk about French rudeness - now I've experienced it! I will rather stick to the nearby Cafe de Flore and Les Deux Magots where customer service and professionalism is taken seriously. Even the hotel restaurants would never even dare to pull such a move!

Super good food, but one of the waitress has no respect for customers. Highly dissapointed with poor attitude without reason. She took my order wrong and begun accusing me of being in the wrong, telling me to “be careful next time cause this one was for free”.

If you want to eat there, you need to register on a weird third party app and give personal data (name, email, phone), that app terms of services or support are both not working, be aware of data leakage.
Not gonna eat there in the future, unless they remove that app.
Overhyped. Average ramen. Chaotic booking system. Terrible atmosphere if you aren't looking for an instagram photo.  Overall wish I had spent my money elsewhere

Ouch, what a disappointment. I'm not an expert on ramen by any means, but I've had ramen in Tokyo and New York, and in the end it matters only if it's tasty anyway.
I had the Kurogoma ramen and boy, let me tell you, was it salty/one-dimensional af. The noodles were also a bit undercooked, but worse than that the chashu pork was completely flavorless and tough (basically impossible to eat properly with chopsticks). Also, ridiculous price increase of 5€ for the chef version - where I didn't taste anything spicy at all (supposedly, there's spicy sauce in the chef version), landing you at 18,50€ - What. The. Hell. Worst dish I've had in a while, especially for this price.
The decor is kinda cool though, so one star for that.

One of worst restaurants ever in Paris

At the first time I liked this place a lot because of the traditional atmosphere. But when I first visited there with my friends, one japanese staff was so rude. She literally yelled at us when we paid: dont touch the screen. Yelling at people in French does not always work. She must keep this in mind. But I tried to understand.

My impression was totally worsened when I went there last sunday night. Six of us went to the restaurant when it opened at 7pm. The staff asked how many people were eating and we said seven because one more friend would come soon. The staff said she could not give us the seat because we all had to get in the restaurant together. I was not that much convinced but this was okay. The real problem was after this. Another staff asked us to get out of the restaurant and wait for our friend outside because our talks could be bothering other people. Me and my japanese friends were shocked and just left.

The taste of ramen was just okay (this is what my japanese friends told me too). Ever since I lived in Paris a few years ago, this is the first experience that I was literally kicked out of the restaurant. The owner must train their staff. Shouting いらっしゃいませ is not everything.
Average ramen. Go elsewhere if you value your time.
Not possible to book online !!((You need to come to them and book at the door on restaurant and just after wait 1.30 hours to come ..  very strange system

Holy cow the food was bad.  The broth tasted like salted water.  Im not able to understand why there was a line-up for this place.  The pork wasnt fresh and the ramen was over cooked.  The seating was uncomfortable.  I think Parisians just don't know good Japanese food so to them this garbage is the best.
If you have had halfway decent ramen or even have somewhat reasonable food standards avoid this place.

Very unfriendly staff, wanted us out fast once we were finished. She placed 2 other people right next to us with no distance and asked us rudely to make more space. On top of that the Ramen was just mediocre, not great.
Noodles are good, but place much overrated. Not worth the usual wait of 1 1/2h during peak. Any other better Ramen place just as good.

Tourist trap do not go. Salty food not tasty at all. It will be your first and last time. The atmosphere is good though but the good part ends there. If you are japanese or have been to japan you will see that this place is a sin. You'll remember this after you eat...

review_text: Went today and it bombed. Badly. The noodles were good, the broth also. But everything else was terrible. The meat was poor, tough and flavour-less, the chicken was especially bad tasting like cheap processed chicken, the pork was just super dry. Coming from London with the likes of bon daddies this place is not worth the 12 Euro. Really sad as my partner and I came to Paris for a holiday and had watched a guy on YouTube (ramen adventures) review it and say the made quality ramen. Sadly not. I'd pay hundreds for good ramen but this was shocking. Everybody don't go. Full stop. Sorry.

Food was pretty good overall but the terrible ambiance combine with exceptionally lackluster service really brought it down. The table was also quite filthy and the walls surrounding the tiny corner I was seated in were covered in grime.

As I understand, the "homemade" Ramen here means they cook it by themselves (which restaurant doesn't?), while it should be Ramen made by human hand. As a few comments here mentioned, I was also forced to take toppings too (for 3 times), "bon appetit" 3 times and "was it good?" 3 times. Come on I just ordered a bowl of Ramen, you guys are not working in a Michelin restaurant. Too much service would be annoying.
The menu is tricky too. "Tamago" simply means egg and "Dashi" is fish soup. But they don't have explanations anywhere.  What would people don't speak Japanese react to such a confusing menu? Unlike the Japanese restaurants at Rue Sainte-Anne, I didn't see any Japanese customers at this restaurant. Reality tells how the food really tastes.

review_text:
Short version: largely overrated, tasteless and yet senselesly salty, light years away from being the best in France or in Europe as some earlier reviews suggested. Do not waste your time queuing for it. It's a trap for tourists and people who don't know much about ramen cuisine.

Long version: I have been to Japan 5 times in many cities, have lived in Asia for 30+ years and 10+ years in Europe and tried countless ramen restaurants. So I consider myself a good authority in rating ramen restaurants.

I had high expectations for Kodawari, as many earlier reviews acclaimed the restaurant to be the best in France / Europe. If you have time and are a real ramen fan, I suggest you take a trip to Toulouse, it's much more worth it.

My impression about Kodawari:
1. The noodles: they were undercooked and therefore failed to absorb the taste of the broth, making the noodles taste like cardboard paper. The noodle type they use (細っ麺) usually (when cooked right) goes well with chicken broth, and yet it was ruined in amateur's hands.

2. The broth: I ordered two different flavors just to do a fair review to the restaurant, one was shoyu ramen with chicken broth and the other was Kaga miso ramen. Both bowls failed to deliver the height of the original recipes, they had no depth nor layers in taste. The shoyu ramen had a faint hint of chicken taste (almost like the broth had been diluted) and the shoyu taste was almost nonexistent (also, it was like if the broth had been diluted very much and just got MSG to raise the umami taste). I barely finished the shoyu ramen, and I couldn't even take half of the Kaga miso ramen soup, it was simply numbingly salty, like a cheap bowl of instant noodles. It was as if the Kaga miso was mixed with some 2nd-grade cheap miso: it didn't taste like anything of what I know about Kaga miso. Two other customers next to me also ordered the Kaga miso ramen and they also said the same: too salty. To give you an idea how salty it is: it's even saltier than Naritake (another well known Ramen restaurant in Paris).

3. The toppings: the pork chashu had no taste and was just stiff and dry, I assume that the meat was overcooked without time to be properly marinated or seasoned and braised over simmering heat (which is the standard Japanese chashu preparation method). In the Kaga miso ramen, they put a slice of eggplant, which I can't understand why, as it was also tasteless and pasty, the texture like a kitchen towel soaked with tooth paste. Toppings in a bowl of ramen are meant to accompany each slurp of noodles by complementing the taste depth and texture.

Conclusion: if the best Japanese ramen I have tried in Europe rates 10, Kodawari is about 4. Do not fall for Kodawari's pretty interior decoration.
Reason: PARTIEL (0.99): review contains generic terms, lacks specific dish details, and has excessive use of ai detection terms indicating possible automatized or non-human creation.

完全西化的一家拉面店，完全不符合亚洲人印象中的拉面，汤底一点鲜味都没有 齁咸，怎么可以长得这么好看吃起来那么难吃… 排了两个小时吃生气了。全场唯一值得的是氛围和装修风格。

Ce restaurant japonais semble plus conçu comme un décor de cinéma qu’un véritable lieu de gastronomie. Tout est orchestré pour donner l’illusion d’un comptoir de street food dans une ruelle japonaise : éclairage tamisé, murs vieillissants en trompe-l’œil, bruits de rue diffusés par des haut-parleurs… Mais l’expérience tourne rapidement à la déception.

Le processus d’attente, imposé par une application qui demande vos données personnelles, est interminable (quasiment 3h !). L’affichage censé indiquer le nombre de personnes avant vous est aussi peu fiable que frustrant, oscillant sans logique apparente. En réalité, on reste debout à patienter des dizaines de minutes tout en voyant d’autres clients entrer avant vous. Cette gestion chaotique du flux finit par agacer.

Une fois à table, le tableau s’effrite davantage. Les plats sont bons, sans être mémorables, et chaque petit extra – œuf, viande ou sauce – vient alourdir l’addition. Comptez facilement près de 20 € pour un bol correct mais loin d’être généreux. Si le bouillon est savoureux, il ne suffit pas à compenser des portions limitées qui ne calent pas sur la durée.

Quant à l’atmosphère, elle sonne creux. Aucun employé n’est japonais, mais on leur demande de crier régulièrement des phrases en pseudo-japonais, probablement pour renforcer le "folklore". Malheureusement, cela ressemble davantage à une mise en scène artificielle qu’à une immersion authentique. L’ensemble donne l’impression d’un piège à touristes qui mise davantage sur le décor et l’ambiance que sur la qualité ou la sincérité de l’expérience.

Ce lieu, vanté par beaucoup, a été pour moi une déception. Entre l’attente interminable, l’authenticité douteuse et un rapport qualité-prix discutable, je ne compte pas y retourner. C’est un exemple parfait de ces adresses qui privilégient l’apparence au détriment du contenu.

P.S. : En montant, je me suis fortement cogné la tête contre un boîtier métallique (visible sur la photo). Ce genre d’élément devrait être protégé ou signalé pour éviter des accidents.

3 ore di attesa e 20 euro in meno nel portafoglio con annessa notte in bianco con i crampi addominali, il pensiero che ci sia gente che fa tutto questo anche una volta a settimana per mangiare questo ramen mi lascia veramente basito. Abbiamo scannerizzato l’app per la fila alle 8, e dalle 8 alle 23 dava 20 minuti di attesa, siamo stesi accolti dopo 3 ore in un micro tavolo con accanto una cassa ad alto volume dove si sentivano solo lamenti come se fossimo alla fiera, abbiamo speso 20 euro per mangiare un ramen insapore, con una mezza fettina di carne, e alla fine siamo stati anche male, meglio una pizza forse sicuramente avrei potuto risparmiare volentieri 2 ore e mezza del mio tempo.

review_text: 어플로 등록후 한 시간 반 뒤에 갔는데 밖에서 한 시간 더 줄서서 기대하며 들어갔는데 일단 라멘이 넘 느끼 ... 레몬과 적양파와 루꼴라가 들어간 면요리 정도 라멘 같지가 않아요 ! 김치부타동에 고기가 불향나서 맛있는데 절대 웨이팅할 맛은 아님🥱

À TOUS LES CONNAISSEURS DE LA CUISINE JAPONAISE !

N'allez pas chez Kodawari Ramen...

C'est tellement dommage que, sous prétexte d'idolâtrer et de chérir cette culture, vous la marketée !
Vous ne vous souciez pas de la saveur de vos plats, vous ne vous souciez pas non plus de votre clientèle, vous ne vous souciez pas de l'image du Japon que vous dégradez petit à petit.

Vos ramen ne sont pas japonais, votre viande n'est pas fraîche puisqu'elle est surgelée (et vous ne vous en cachez pas).
C'est pourtant dommage, vous qui vantez la qualité de vos produits. Vous vantez la qualité d'un produit qui doit décongeler pendant de longues minutes devant l'intégralité des clients du comptoir...

Le bouillon du ramen Kurogoma (leur spécialité) est IN-BU-VABLE. Étant un fervent amateur de ramen sauce sésame noir et ail, je n'ai rien mangé.
Les tamago (œufs) sont farineux et immondes. Il ne suffit pas d'acheter, de décongeler et de tout mélanger pour que vos ramen soient bons.

Vos cuisiniers et salariés n'ont malheureusement pas l'air passionné par le Japon, ils sont le fruit d'un restaurant qui marche bien.

Le restaurant est petit, étroit, le comptoir est minuscule et trop long. Vous avez fait un restaurant à l'ambiance Yokocho mais il est trop petit. Les clients et serveurs passent leur temps à vous toucher lors de leur passage derrière vous.

Près d'un quart d'heure pour un verre d'umeshu mais trois petites minutes pour deux ramen... C'est suspect.
En même temps, au vu du prix de deux ramen contenants des nouilles et de l'eau salée et/ou amère, on comprend qu'ils s'empressent de vous servir.

Un serveur lent, inefficace et insolent comme j'en ai rarement vu...
La première fois que le serveur nous a apporté notre boisson : c'était la mauvaise.
Ma compagne a demandé plusieurs fois son verre d'umeshu au même serveur. J'arrête sans aucune once de méchanceté ce même garçon qui, en me répondant, ne trouve rien de plus amusant à faire que de me corriger sur ma manière de prononcer le mot "umeshu"...

Les clients à côté de nous au comptoir ont été installé sur une table non-débarrassée, pas nettoyée et par conséquent pas redressée. Vous gérez mal l'installation de votre clientèle.

Nous sommes venus souriants, contents des tester un nouveau plat de ramen. Nous sommes reparti déçus, très peu satisfaits voire mécontents.

En résumé, une attente longue, une carte chère, des plats absolument pas à la hauteur de votre réputation. Une base de ramen d'amateur, beaucoup de charabia pour des produits de qualité (que l'on retrouve dans d'autres restaurants japonais de ramen). Je ne conseille absolument pas ce restaurant qui cible son chiffre d'affaires plutôt sur que la perfection d'un ramen bien fait.

PS : À titre personnel et en me basant sur mes nombreuses expériences, je vous conseille vivement d'essayer d'autres restaurants de ramen.
Reason: PARTIEL (0.98): 1. Primary violation category: 7 - Offensive content\n2. Brief explanation: The review contains deliberately provocative language and unproven allegations of wrongdoing, such as accusing the restaurant of degrading the image of Japan and serving non-fresh, frozen meat. It also includes personal attacks on the staff, describing them as inefficient and insolent.\n3. Confidence level: High

Hygiène à revoir ! NOUS SOMMES TOMBÉS MALADE !

Tout d’abord il y a énormément de monde et une très longue file d’attente avec un QR code mais passons.

Nous étions deux à venir manger un ramen, et tous les deux nous sommes tombés malade à en vomir dans la nuit. Il doit y avoir un sacré problème d’hygiène dans le restaurant !

Il y a également très peu de place pour s’asseoir et vous êtes entassés, les serveurs hurlent des mots en japonais (Enfin ils essayent pour vous donner l’illusion, car aucun japonais ne travaille là-bas)

Les serveurs vous forcent la main pour que vous donniez un pourboire sur leur machine (Ce qui n’existe pas au Japon, et en France non plus d’ailleurs)

En bref, je ne recommande pas à moins que vous voulez une expérience traumatisante et faussement japonaise

review_text: Les ramens sont très bons (bien qu’un peu trop salé pour le ramen « spécialité »). En revanche, le service et l’organisation sont désastreux : nous avons dû attendre 1h30 dehors sous la pluie et dans le froid car l’application d’attente a eu des bugs et le temps d’attente ne faisait que se rallonger. Aucun geste commercial n’a été proposé. À l’intérieur, j’ai été en permanence bousculé par les serveurs qui passaient ou bien le cuisiner qui déplaçait des marmites de soupe géante. Ce n’était vraiment pas agréable. C’est dommage car j’avais adoré l’autre kodawari « poisson ».

Une belle façade pour une énorme déception.
Dès l’entrée, le restaurant impressionne : une déco magnifique, une ambiance chaleureuse, tout donne envie de s’installer et de passer un bon moment. Malheureusement, l’attente est interminable, et quand enfin les plats arrivent… c’est la catastrophe.

Le poulet ? Une horreur. Il sent mauvais, il est gluant et semble à la limite de la fraîcheur. Le bouillon ? Une mare d’huile écœurante, sans aucune saveur digne de ce nom. Autant dire que l’expérience culinaire est un désastre complet.

Un bel endroit pour prendre une photo, mais surtout pas pour manger. À éviter.

review_text:
Je n'ai jamais été aussi mal assis que dans ce restaurant. Pas de place pour les jambes et on se fait bousculer par les clients et serveurs car c'est trop petit.
On était à côté de la porte d'entrée, qui est majoritairement ouverte à cause des nombreux va et vient.

Donc le froid + les serveurs qui crient dans nos oreilles dès qu'il y a des clients qui rentrent, l'assise catastrophique et les prix trop élevés de la carte = aucun plaisir.

Ça faisait longtemps qu'on voulait essayer avec ma femme car on a entendu que des bons retours, on y retournera pas.

Le service est sans faute même si pas hyper chaleureux (après je leur en veux pas ça doit être épuisant de bosser là dedans et c'était dimanche soir), la déco est superbe et ça reproduit vraiment pas mal Omoide Yokocho à Tokyo et l'étage offre une expérience assez particulière... mais alors les ramens sont tellement décevants ! C'est fade, le bouillon manque vraiment de saveur et ils sont vraiment très pauvrement garnis. Ca vaut absolument pas le coup de vagabonder dans le quartier pendant 1h30 avant de pouvoir enfin manger ça.. pour considérer ca comme de bons ramens faut probablement ne jamais en avoir mangé de vrais parce que ceux là n'ont vraiment pas de goût.

Je ne comprends pas l’engouement autour de ce restaurant. Ce n’est pas bon, j’ai failli vomir en mangeant le ramen, on vous fait asseoir dans des petites places peu confortables et le système de la queue est mal géré. J’ai mangé des ramen bien meilleurs, dans des restaurants plus confortables et chaleureux.

Je n’ai pas à me plaindre de la qualité du plat en lui même mais des prix exorbitants qui ne valent absolument pas cela en comparaison de la qualité, c’est bon mais sans plus, pour quelqu’un qui a déjà mangé de véritables ramen au Japon vous serez déçu c’est clair.

review_text: Das Essen war meiner Meinung nach Ok (4/10) aber mehr auch nicht. Die Wartezeit ist sehr lange. Der Service ist schnell. Das Ambiente ist „gewöhnungsbedürftig“. Es ist definitiv kein Lokal um länger zu verweilen. Die Stühle (Hocker) sind klein und sehr eng zusammen gestellt. Es ist kalt im inneren und alles ziemlich eng. Zudem wird ständig ein hintergrundgeräusch über Boxen abgespielt was einfach nur nervt. Mir ist bewusst das es so gewollt ist. Nur für mich war es nichts.

Avis mitigé… tout d’abord : un temps d’attente beaucoup trop long (il faut trouver une solution pour cela c’est infernal). Nous y avons mangé un soir et ils ont reçu une livraison assez tard la porte restait donc ouverte et il faisait super froid (pas agréable pour manger). Ensuite les serveur•es sont trop insistants pour les pourboires c’est presque gênant. Et lors du paiement une serveuse m’a retiré le TPE d’un coup pour pas que je paye avec ma carte ticket restau… pas sûr que ce soit très légal. Je n’y retournerai pas, je préfère celui Rue Richelieu (Tsukiji) ! Sinon les Ramen étaient bons mais pas exceptionnels non plus ! On ne peut pas leur enlever que c’est un bon rapport qualité/prix en revanche !

nous avons attendu 2H pour rentrer dans ce restaurant pour finalement être placé près d’un câble électrique ( et non, ce n’était pas la déco, comme une de vos collaboratrice disait). Nous avons reçu un sms pour nous dire qu’il restait 10 min avant qu’on ne soit placé et finalement, on s’est retrouvé à poireauter de l’autre coté de la ru car votre serveuse ne savait pas quoi faire.
Arrivé à l’intérieur et installé avec d’autres personnes dans le restaurant, on a pas eu un menu, personne n’est venu nous demander si on voulait être servi… bref, on ne nous a pas calculer alors qu’on a fait la queue 2H pour goûter les fameux ramen… Bien évidemment, une personne est revenue prendre la commande de la table avec qui on a été placé ( je précise que ces personnes sont entrés avec nous , on aurait donc dû être servi avec eux!!! ) mais ils passaient commandes et on avait pas encore reçu le menu du resto.
Donc au final, nous sommes partis, le ventre vide , après 2H d’attente .
si je peux conseiller quelque chose aux personnes qui lira mon avis : il y a d’autres restaurants avec un personnel plus sympa et un service plus respectueux que celui ci…

Vraiment trop trop trop long !
Je suis venu un samedi avec des amis et nous avons attendu 3h!
L'application nous disait au départ 2h et il était impossible de réserver 1 table pour 6 même après avoir demandé à la dame qui gère la file d'attente, elle nous dit de réserver 2 tables de 3 et de me signaler lorsqu'on reviendra.
Une fois les 2h passées, on revient et demande à être à 6 et la dame arrive finalement à changer notre réservation sauf qu'il faut rajouter encore 30 minutes!
Après avoir attendu 2h on pouvait bien attendre 30 minutes.
Sauf qu'après ces 30 minutes elle nous dit qu'en fait ce temps d'attente correspond au temps avant d'arriver dans la vraie file et que ensuite il faut encore compter une quinzaine de minutes avant qu'une table se libère.
Bref nous avons eu notre table après 3h d'attente.

Côté repas, les plats étaient bons, un peu déçu qu'il n'y ai qu'un seul plat végétarien, tous les autres plats avec du porc et aucun avec du poisson. Le plat version chef est bon et assez copieux mais quand même cher (19.50)

Bref ça ne vaut pas le coup d'attendre aussi longtemps et payer aussi cher.

Allergiques aux arachides, passez votre chemin.

Je suis actuellement en voyage en France, et pour l’occasion, j’avais vraiment envie de goûter ce ramen dont j’entends parler si souvent. Avant de m’y rendre, j’ai bien sûr pris le temps de me renseigner pour savoir si mon allergie poserait un problème. Tout semblait indiquer que non.

Une fois sur place, après 45 minutes d’attente, on s’installe avec mon groupe et on commence à regarder le menu. Avant de commander, j’informe la serveuse de mon allergie. Elle part se renseigner, revient avec un papier rouge pour que j’y note mon allergie, puis me demande si elle est mortelle. Je réponds que "oui".

Son attitude déjà peu chaleureuse me mettait mal à l’aise, mais sa réponse fut encore pire : "Nous ne vous servirons pas."

C’est bien la première fois qu’on me refuse un service aussi directement. Aucune explication : est-ce que le bouillon contient des arachides ? Y a-t-il une alternative ? Absolument rien.
On m’a simplement proposé de commander une boisson.

Finalement, je décide de partir. Avant de quitter, on demande à d’autres serveurs, qui avaient l’air un peu plus aimables, pourquoi on m’a refusé. On m’explique alors qu’il y a déjà eu un incident dans le passé, ce qui les rend réticents à servir des clients avec une telle allergie.

Je peux comprendre que ce genre d’incident ait pu être marquant et qu’ils veuillent éviter d’en revivre un autre. Mais honnêtement, une meilleure façon de gérer la situation aurait fait toute la différence. Là, j’ai juste eu l’impression d’être un "problème" ou une cliente "différente". La manière dont ça a été dit m’a vraiment fait me sentir mal.

Je pense qu’il serait essentiel d’indiquer clairement sur votre site ou votre menu les risques liés aux allergènes. Surtout que rien n’était mentionné concernant la présence d’arachides dans vos plats, à part une note demandant d’avertir le serveur. En Europe, selon le règlement n°1169/2011, les allergènes doivent être clairement identifiés.

Pour un restaurant aussi bien noté et apprécié, je trouve ça assez choquant. La gestion des allergènes devrait être irréprochable : séparer les aliments, nettoyer les ustensiles, former le personnel à mieux gérer ce genre de situation. On ne peut pas tout éviter, mais un minimum est attendu, surtout pour des allergies graves.

Bref, je suis vraiment déçue de cet accueil et de cette expérience.  Déjà qu’annoncer une allergie à un serveur n’est jamais facile, être traité de la sorte rendra mes futures sorties au restaurant encore plus angoissantes.

J’espère que mon témoignage pourra éviter à d’autres une telle mésaventure et vous encouragera à améliorer vos pratiques.

La ramen est délicieux, cependant quasiment trois heures d'attente (avec une queue virtuelle pour deux heures et demi qui vous amène à une deuxième queue devant le restaurant pour encore une trentaine de minutes) tenant en compte que c'était un dimanche soir, la ça commence à perdre du sens à mon avis. Après 3h d'attente - dont 15 minutes sous la pluie - et à peine rentré dans le restaurant - les serveurs nous ont dit que la cuisine fermait et qu'il fallait commander immédiatement. Pas le temps de laisser ma copine rentrer des toilettes ils sont allé la chercher devant la porte avec le menu.

La qualité du Ramen - que j'ai trouvé délicieux ne compense pas le service désagréable.

review_text:
Accueil était extrêmement sympathique. Salle pleine encore a 14h mais nous n'avons pas attendu (table de 2)

Je vais maintenant parler de ce qui ne va pas : lieu absolument pas accessible pour une personne en situation de handicap moteur (sauf peut-être en restant à l'avant du restaurant, mais n'espérez pas avoir accès aux toilettes).

Toilettes, justement, à l'étage en haut d'un escalier pentu. Toilettes Japonaises qui ne fonctionnent pas (dommage). Rien pour accrocher son sac mais a la limite, ce n'est pas grave). Par contre pour redescendre, il ne faut pas avoir mal aux genoux ou le vertige : les marches sont assez hautes et pas de rampes pour se maintenir. Attention à la dernière marche qui est traître).

L'ambiance sonore est assommante. L'idée est sympathique, on a l'impression d'être dans une rue au Japon. Mais vraiment, revoyez le niveau sonore. Personne ne s'entend et résultat, tout le monde parle très fort, c'est insupportable.

Concernant la cuisine, nous avons été assez déçues : certes, le goût est là et c'est très bon, mais sans topping, on n'a qu'une tranche de viande, quelques pousses de bambou et CEST TOUT. Dans un Ramen, il y a au minimum un œuf, des feuilles d'algues. Mais là... Pas de petit profit : il faut payer pour en avoir. Alors oui, c'est très bon mais très décevant. 2€ pour un œuf et 1€50 pour quelques feuilles d'algues...

Nous avions décidé de prendre un the vert (nous en prenons toujours en restaurant Asiatique de qualité). PASSEZ VOTRE CHEMIN : c'est un the en bouteille sans goût ! Payer 4€50 pour une boisson que nous n'avons pu finir de par son goût vraiment flotteux (un the à le goût de the, pas de flotte avec un peu d'herbe dedans !) est inacceptable.

Seulement deux desserts à la carte... Mouais...

On a un peu l'impression d'être arrivés dans un attrape-touriste, alors que la cuisine est délicieuse. Bref, très déçue alors que ça pourrait être un 5*.

Seul point positif, le staff très aimable. Il y’a beaucoup d’autres meilleurs restaurants à Paris.

Tres mauvaise expérience. Les ramens sont trop gras. Je me suis sentie mal toute la soirée après. En plus après avoir attendu 2h… je ne sais pas pourquoi ce restaurant est si convoité.
Le concept est bien mais trop bruyant et on est mis très vite dehors à cause des autres personnes qui attendent

J’ai procrastiné pour écrire cet avis tant la frustration est grande et des mots plein d’aigreur me viennent à l’esprit.

Rien n’allait, rien de rien, et le tout était d’autant plus déstabilisant qu’on est face à un haut lieu pour lequel je n’ai entendu que des superlatifs : le meilleur ramen de Paris, le plus authentique, l’atmosphère la plus sympa… et j’en passe. Le personnel semble en être convaincu et ça rend le tout on ne peut plus gênant pour le client qui commence par manger une minuscule entrée à 6 euros, sans saveur aucune, et qui se demande ce qui l’attend pour le ramen en se disant que, après tout, il aurait peut être fallu commander uniquement ce pour quoi ils sont plébiscités. Eh bien non, la chute a continué : j’ai vu le ramen le plus tristement composé, bu le bouillon le plus gras, et mangé le poulet le plus insipide de ma vie. Oui, c’est décidément un restaurant qui mérite les superlatifs.

Pour augmenter le supplice et accabler tous nos sens, on nous fait le plaisir de mettre en fond sonore un bruit supposé imiter l’effervescence des rues tokyoites. Parce que ça n’est pas suffisant et pour réserver le meilleur des accueils aux nouveaux arrivants, la serveuse crie (un truc sympa en japonais j’imagine ?) à intervalle de temps régulier en passant dans l’allée. C’est troublant au possible.

Vous serez plus satisfaits dans n’importe quel autre modeste restaurant asiatique du coin qui propose sans fioriture le ramen parmi d’autres spécialités, avec ou sans miso maison, plus ou moins authentique, avec un vilain soupçon de glutamate s’il le faut. On ne me fera pas croire que mon palet n’est pas assez éduqué ou que j’ai rien compris, ça ne viendra que confirmer la prétention excessive que je prête à ce lieu.

Entre la gestion des arrivées interminables et désagréables, le repas avec peu de saveurs ou encore la manque de nettoyage du restaurant ; je ne sais pas où commencer. Je vais procéder par ordre temporel.

Le cadre quant à lui relève la note. L'ambiance est sympathique si l'on ne fait pas attention à la poussière visible sur de nombreux objets.

4. 進入店內後，等了50分鐘麵才來，店家有告知製麵機器故障
5. 點了啤酒，但啤酒杯沒冰過，還是溫的，等於是在幫我啤酒加溫

Not as good as I thought so I don’t recommend it at all. It would be better if the beer glass is frozen, and the water glass is dirty as the picture shown. The dining environment is in good Japanese street vibe.

review_text:
Ramen bastante bueno, pero no creo que merezca la pena por las 2h de cola. El trato no es el más agradable.

Además, no tienen opciones sin gluten y al momento de comunicar que eres celíaco, te invitan a desalojar el restaurante.
